SUMMARY: NESTED | FIELD | CONSTR | METHOD DETAIL: FIELD | CONSTR | METHOD

com.esri.mo2.file.shp
Class Shapefile

java.lang.Object
  |
  +--com.esri.mo2.file.shp.Shapefile
public class Shapefile
extends Object

This class manages Shapefiles. This includes both the geometry and attribute components.

When creating shapefiles, please note that you must create and add at least one attribute field.

The following code snippet shows how to read a shapefile using the Shapefile, ShapefileRecord, DbfField, and PointShp classes. This example reads and displays all of the fields and values to the system console.

int i; int j; int numRecs; int numFields; DbfField[] fields; Object object; Shapefile shp; ShapefileRecord shpRec; PointShp pntShp; double x,y; try { shp= new Shapefile("points"); shp.openReadOnly(); if (shp.getFileType()!=ShapeTypes.POINT) { System.out.println("This is not a point shapefile"); return; } fields= shp.getAttributeFields(); numFields= fields.length + 1; numRecs= shp.getNumRecs(); //display field names for (i=0; i<numFields; i++) { if (i==0) { //the first field is always the shape field System.out.print("Point\t"); } else { System.out.print(fields[i-1].getName() + "\t"); } } System.out.println(); //display field values for (i=1; i<=numRecs; i++) { shpRec= shp.getRecord(i); if (shpRec.getStatus() != ShapefileRecord.OK) continue; for (j=0; j<numFields; j++) { object= shpRec.getValue(j); if (j==0) { //shape data x= ((PointShp)object).getXAt(0); y= ((PointShp)object).getYAt(0); System.out.print(x + "," + y + "\t"); } else System.out.print(object.toString() + "\t"); } System.out.println(); } shp.close(); } catch (Exception e) { System.out.println("exception thrown"); } The following code snippet shows how to create a point shapefile using the Shapefile, ShapefileRecord, DbfField, and PointShp clases. Please note that a shapefile must contain at least one attribute field. This example creates a point shapefile than contains 10 records and one attribute field. int i; int n; int intVal; DbfField integerField; Shapefile shp; ShapefileRecord shpRec; double x,y; PointShp pntShp; try { shp= new Shapefile("points"); shp.openNew(ShapeTypes.POINT); n=10; //no need to define a shape field //define attribute field integerField= DbfField.create("REC_ID",Types.INTEGER,9,0); shp.addAttributeField(integerField); intVal=0; x=0.0; y=0.0; for (i=1; i<=n; i++) { shpRec= shp.createRecord(); //get default shape from record pntShp= (PointShp)shpRec.getValue(0); //since shape is NULL, set number of points pntShp.setNumPoints(1); pntShp.setXAt(0,x); pntShp.setYAt(0,y); shpRec.setValue(0,pntShp); x=x+1.0; y=y+1.0; shpRec.setValue(1,new Integer(intVal)); intVal++; shp.putRecord(shpRec); if (shpRec.getStatus()==ShapefileRecord.OK) System.out.println("Record "+i+" written ok"); else System.out.println("Record "+i+" has error"); } shp.close(); } catch (Exception e) { System.out.println("exception thrown"); }

FILE_CODEPAGE

public static final int FILE_CODEPAGE
this constant value is used with the isAvailable() method to determine the presence of an optional codepage file. This file has the extension of "cpg".

putRecord

public void putRecord(ShapefileRecord rec)
               throws IOException

Parameters:

Throws:
IOException - if an I/O error occurs

putRecord

public void putRecord(ShapefileRecord rec,
                      int recnum)
Writes a shapefile record at the specified position in the file. The status of the record is updated after it is written to the file.

Parameters:
rec - the shapefile record
recnum - record number to write

delRecord

public int delRecord(int recnum)
Flags the specified record as deleted. This method does not actually remove the record from the file.

Parameters:
recnum - rec to delete
Returns:
ShapefileRecord.OK if successful, ShapefileRecord.BAD otherwise
